channel.title: BBC News - Science & Environment

item.title: Climate change: Europe's extreme rains made more likely by humans
item.description: Heavy rainfall that led to deadly floods in Germany and Belgium was influenced by human induced warming.

item.title: Pulsar discoverer awarded Royal Society's highest prize
item.description: Astrophysicist Dame Jocelyn Bell Burnell is only the second woman to be awarded the Copley Medal.

item.title: Nature crisis: Talks resume on global plan to protect biodiversity
item.description: UN negotiators have resumed work on a plan to protect at least 30% of the world's land and oceans.

item.title: From earrings to tiles â€“ what you can do with plastic waste
item.description: How people around the world are recycling plastic waste themselves and turning it into cool stuff.

item.title: Climate change: Will I still be able to fly in a net zero world?
item.description: A new study asks if lifestyle changes including an end to flying will be necessary to reach net zero?

item.title: Baby bats babble like humans
item.description: Babbling in baby bats bears a striking resemblance to human infants learning to talk, researchers find.

item.title: Nature: Rattlesnakes' sound 'trick' fools human ears
item.description: Rattlesnakes have evolved a clever method of convincing humans that danger is closer than you think.

item.title: CFC ban bought time to fight climate change - scientists
item.description: A global treaty banning ozone-depleting chemicals in 1987 may have averted a climate catastrophe today.

item.title: Reared curlews act like wild counterparts after release in Norfolk
item.description: Tracking devices show movements of curlew after their release into the wild.

item.title: Hydrogen power offers jobs boost, says government
item.description: Kick-starting a hydrogen industry could attract billions in investment, the UK government says.

item.title: Images show decline of California's 'life source'
item.description: Justin Sullivan has been following California's second-largest reservoir's falling water levels.

item.title: Council policies 'inconsistent' with climate goals
item.description: A third of English councils support policies that could increase emissions, BBC research suggests.

item.title: Climate change: July world's hottest month ever recorded - US agency
item.description: US scientists say July's land and ocean temperature was 0.93C (1.68F) above the 20th Century average.

item.title: Climate change: Five things we have learned from the IPCC report
item.description: What are the key takeaways from the IPCC new study on the science of climate change?

item.title: Climate Check: Why a warmer world will also be wetter
item.description: Human activity is causing unprecedented changes in our climate - that's the main message in the latest report from the IPCC. In this month's Climate Check, Ben Rich explains why a warmer world will also be a wetter one.

item.title: Climate change: IPCC report is 'code red for humanity'
item.description: Heating from humans has caused irreparable damage to the Earth that may get worse in coming decades.

item.title: Astronomers see galaxies in ultra-high definition
item.description: Researchers capture some of the most detailed images ever seen of galaxies in deep space.

item.title: Bezos sues Nasa over its deal with Elon Musk's SpaceX
item.description: Mr Bezos's Blue Origin says it was unfairly treated after being excluded from lunar landing contract.

item.title: UK military opens first space command centre
item.description: The new operations centre will help the UK maintain a "battle-winning advantage", ministers say.

item.title: Russian module mishap destabilises International Space Station
item.description: The ISS was pushed out of position after engines on a new Russian module unexpectedly fired up.

item.title: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft: A guide
item.description: Starliner is one of two vehicles designed to transport astronauts to and from the space station.

item.title: US lab stands on threshold of key nuclear fusion goal
item.description: A US science institute is on the verge of achieving a longstanding goal in nuclear fusion research.

item.title: The zero-power sewage plant inspired by cows
item.description: Fifty sustainable sewage treatment plants have been built that work in similar way to a cow's stomach.

item.title: Extreme weather: How is it connected to climate change?
item.description: Heatwaves, wildfires, floods and droughts highlight how extreme weather is linked to climate change.

item.title: There and back again: The epic adventures of China's wandering elephants
item.description: After a mammoth journey across the country the pack of pachyderms are finally heading home.

item.title: How do we slow down fast fashion?
item.description: The clothes we wear can have a huge impact on the climate, even more so than the aviation industry.

item.title: Will I ever be able to fly again without feeling guilty?
item.description: More efficient planes and sustainable fuels could lower air travel's impact, but not for a while.

item.title: The illegal gold mines killing rivers and livelihoods in Ghana
item.description: Sixty percent of Ghana's water bodies are now polluted, largely due to illegal mining operations.

item.title: How are wildfires linked to climate change?
item.description: A series of major wildfires across the world has hit the headlines - how do they compare to previous years?

item.title: Climate change: How to be more eco-friendly in everyday life
item.description: From food to fashion, green bloggers give their top tips to be more eco-friendly.
